course_title: Methods for Literary Research: Moby-Dick & Of One Blood
class_notes:
Course Topic: Moby-Dick and Of One Blood
In this course, students will learn about different approaches to literary criticism and scholarship through intensive investigation of two fascinating, globe-spanning American novels: Herman Melville's Moby-Dick (1851) and Pauline Hopkins' Of One Blood (1902). Melville's novel was a total flop at the time of its publication but went on to become celebrated as a visionary work of art in the twentieth and twenty-first century. It has inspired a dizzying array of critical responses grounded in critical race theory, ecocriticism, animal studies, queer theory, disability studies, postcolonial theory and more. Set against a backdrop of racial injustice, Of One Blood is a thrilling tale of adventure, intrigue, and fantasy, involving the discovery of an ancient Wakanda-like civilization in Ethiopia. One of four serialized novels published by the important African American journalist and editor Pauline Hopkins, it was long-neglected but has recently inspired archival research and wide-ranging critical scholarship, which connects the novel to debates about race, politics, spirituality, and psychology. Through short writing assignments and in-class presentations, students will explore how these works have been enlisted in a wider set of critical conversations; these will build toward final research projects in which students contribute to a scholarly conversation of their own curation.
course_description: This course introduces students to the methods and materials of academic literary research and criticism. Focusing on a small body of literature and scholarship within one area of study, the course will teach students to engage with secondary sources, including contextual and/or archival material.
